Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Family Structure and Inequality in Contemporary America

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the last three decades, economic inequality among families in the United States has increased. One of the likely drivers of rising inequality is the changing familial landscape, especially the steep decline in the percentage of children living in married-parent families. Notably, other factors related to the structural and economic context of modern American life were also changing and may have also contributed to economic inequality among families. This project analyzes economic inequality among families with children in the contemporary United States. This project will be the first to simultaneously investigate several features of the contemporary American landscape. The goal is to understand 1) how family income and wealth vary by key characteristics of families, such as whether families include one or two parents and, if two parents, whether the parents are married, and 2) how these associations between family characteristics and family economic resources have changed over the time period of 1980-2013.

The data, for the years 1980-2013, come from the Current Population Survey and the Survey of Income and Program Participation. Families with at least one resident child under the age of 18 will be classified into one of seven family types. The study will
decompose changes in family economic resources into between- and within-family type components and estimate income volatility, within family type, using both the standard deviation and permanent and transitory variances of family income. The PIs consider both static measures of, and over-time changes in family structure. This project examines factors that may affect family economic resources that have not been fully explored in previous research, including year-to-year changes in parental wages and earned income, changes in resources that families receive from government programs and tax credits such as the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC), and stability in the number of adults living in the family household. Additionally, we will examine differences across families in wealth and debts, in addition to differences in income. Our results will help social scientists understand how changes in American families are related to growing income and wealth inequality, and whether changes in government programs and taxes are widening economic inequalities among children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project investigates the tremendous increase in economic inequality in recent decades in the United States. We interrogate whether and how changes in family structure contribute to economic inequality among families with children, yielding insights that are crucial to crafting appropriate public policies to alleviate poverty and economic deprivation among children. Our research also informs scholarly questions about what changes in the economy, public policies, and families contribute to changes in household wealth and income holdings in the United States. 

Previous research has investigated poverty and income inequality among families with children, but very few studies of families with children have focused on wealth. This is an important oversight because research suggests that parental wealth strongly impacts children’s educational attainment and successful transition to adulthood.

In the first analysis from this project, we compare trends from 1989 to 2013 for wealth levels of the two groups that comprise “America’s dependents:” the elderly and households with children. Life cycle theory predicts that elderly households have more wealth than households with children because elderly households build up assets and savings during their working years whereas families with children have younger household heads, more expenses, and fewer years to amass saving. We investigate the idea that these wealth gaps between families with children and elderly households may be dynamic, changing with labor market conditions and the broader economic and policy context. We find that the wealth gap between elderly households and households with children  increased substantially between 1989 and 2013. Moreover, this increasing gap was not driven by the increasing wealth of the “1 percent;” instead, the gap between elderly households and households with children grew most among the least wealthy households. Increasing racial diversity and single parenthood among households with children do not explain the growing gap. Our findings suggest that elderly households benefitted from the indexing of Social Security payments to inflation whereas families with children were disadvantaged by increased educational debts, the result of increases in the share of young adults attending college coupled with increasing tuition costs.

In the second part of the project, we present the first analyses of trends over time in wealth inequality by family structure for all working-age households in the United States. We find that married-parent families have substantially higher net worth than other family structures, including married couples without children. We find that family structure wealth gaps have remained relatively stable during a period of rising wages for more educated workers and changing characteristics of the population of married parents. Differences in household incomes and the demographic characteristics of household heads do not fully account for this gap. Different patterns of investments, specifically home ownership, explain most of the remaining gap. In particular, married-parent families are much more likely to own their home, and home ownership is the primary means of wealth accumulation among all but the wealthiest households in the United States.

In a third part of our project, we assess racial gaps in wealth poverty between 2004 and 2013 for families with children. This paper, which is the first to assess how the Great Recession impacted racial differences in wealth for families with children, presents a sobering story of increased racial inequality. Whereas the Great Recession had almost no impact on the net worth of the wealthiest white families, it halved the net worth of the wealthiest Black and Hispanic families and decimated the net worth of the least wealthy families of every racial group. Wealth gaps were greater in 2013 than before the Great Recession. Widening wealth gaps occurred among both homeowners and renters, suggesting that disproportionate losses in home values in racial minority neighborhoods is not the only explanation for widening racial wealth gaps.
